mnd7:1.2: Those who engage in lust, dear sir!
mnd7:1.3: Please tell of of the distress,
mnd7:1.5: We will learn by staying away.
mnd7:1.7: Those who engage in lust, dear sir!

mnd7:1.22: Those who engage in lust, dear sir!
mnd7:1.23: Please tell of of the distress,
mnd7:1.25: We will learn by staying away.
mnd7:2.1: "Person who engages in lust": Whoever is not doing justice, vulgar dhamma filthy
mnd7:2.2: dhamma, vulgarity, waterside washing, secret, one-on-one, etc. [AN.7.50] is the
mnd7:2.3: dhamma of lust. For what reason is it called the dhamma of lust? It belongs to
mnd7:2.4: two people who are greedy, full of desire and greed, entangled, the heart is
mnd7:2.5: overwhelmed, and two people are in the same way. For that reason, it is called
mnd7:2.6: the dhamma of lust. For example, if there are two quarrelers, they are called
mnd7:2.7: "fornicators;" there are two disputers, and they are called "fornicators;" there
mnd7:2.8: are two discussants, and they are called "fornicators;" there are two disputers,
mnd7:2.9: they are called "fornicators;" there are two advocators, they are called
mnd7:2.10: "fornicators;" there are two speakers, they are called "fornicators;" there are
mnd7:2.11: two interlocutors, they are called "fornicators." In the same way, (it) belongs
mnd7:2.12: to two people who are greedy, full of desire and greed, entangled, whose heart
mnd7:2.13: is overwhelmed, and two people are in the same way.
mnd7:3.1: "One who engages in lust": The one who puts on the harness, the strong harness,
mnd7:3.2: the one who faces the harness, the one who fully faces the harness, the one who
mnd7:3.3: practices, the one who repeats, the one who emphasizes, the one who tends to
mnd7:3.4: incline, the one who increases, that person.
mnd7:4.1: "[Like this Venerable Tissa Metteyya]": "Like this," the continuation of the
mnd7:4.2: sentences, the connection of the words, the completion of the sentences, the
mnd7:4.3: combination of words, this is the order of the sentence, which is "like this."
mnd7:4.4: "Venerable," this is a synonym of love, respect, and obedience. "Tissa," the
mnd7:4.5: name, title, security of the Brāhmaṇa, title, word, phrase. "Metteyya," the
mnd7:4.6: Brāhmaṇa's surname, name, title, and common name. (Some translations treat Tissa
mnd7:4.7: and Metteyya as names of two separate people, but that is apparently incorrect;
mnd7:4.8: as explained here, Tissa is his personal name, and Metteyya is his surname. This
mnd7:4.9: Tissa Metteyya is unlikely to be the same person as in the second sutta of the
mnd7:4.10: Way to the Far Shore section.)
mnd7:5.1: "Dear Sir! Please speak of the distress": "distress," annoyance, injury,
mnd7:5.2: oppression, blow, harm, disaster. Please say, please explain, please teach,
mnd7:5.3: please inform, please establish, please uncover, please analyze, please clarify.
mnd7:5.4: "Dear Sir," "This is a love language, a respectful language, an obedient
mnd7:6.1: "After hearing your teachings": "Your speech, language, teachings, admonitions,
mnd7:6.2: after hearing, after grasping, after understanding, after discriminating.
mnd7:7.1: "We will learn by staying away (seclusion)": "Being away," there are three types
mnd7:7.2: of being away: away in body, away in mind, and away in adherence. What is bodily
mnd7:7.3: staying away? Here, the bhikkhu is close to the solitary residence: woods,
mnd7:7.4: trees, mountains, caverns, grottos, cemeteries, forests, open fields, straw
mnd7:7.5: piles, living away with the body, he walks alone, stands alone, sits alone, lies
mnd7:7.6: alone, enters the village alone for alms, returns alone, sitting alone in the
mnd7:7.7: quiet place, alone doing the practice, walking, staying, acting, going on,
mnd7:7.8: guarding, surviving, and living alone, is to stay away bodily.
mnd7:8.1: What is keeping the mind away? The mind of the person who enters the first jhāna
mnd7:8.2: has been far away from the covers, the mind of the person who has entered the
mnd7:8.3: second jhāna has been far away from reasoning and thinking, the mind of the
mnd7:8.4: person who has entered the third jhāna has been far away from joy, and the mind
mnd7:8.5: of the person who has entered the fourth jhāna has been separated from happiness
mnd7:8.6: and suffering; the mind of the person who enters the boundless void (fifth/first
mnd7:8.7: immaterial) has already thought to stay away from thought and to be far away
mnd7:8.8: from all types of desires, the mind of the person who enters the boundlessness
mnd7:8.9: of consciousness (sixth) has wanted to stay away from the boundless void, the
mnd7:8.10: mind of the person who has entered nothingness (seventh) has thought to stay way
mnd7:8.11: from the boundlessness of consciousness; (and the mind of the person who has
mnd7:8.12: entered neither-perception-nor-non-perception) has no thoughts, and wants to
mnd7:9.1: The mind of the Sotāpanna person has changed from seeing, suspicious, forbidden,
mnd7:9.2: seeing the potential trend of defilement, the potential trend of doubt
mnd7:9.3: defilement, and the pollution of existence is far away. The heart of the
mnd7:9.4: Sakadāgāmī has changed from the rough desire and greed knot, the disgust knot,
mnd7:9.5: the latent tendency of the rough desire, greed and trouble, the potential trend
mnd7:9.6: of disgust and trouble, and the pollution of the same existence. The remaining
mnd7:9.7: knots of desire and greed, disgust, from the remaining potential trends of
mnd7:9.8: desire, greed, disgust, and the pollution that exist with them, the Arahant's
mnd7:9.9: heart has changed from formed greed, formless greed, conceit, aversion,
mnd7:9.10: ignorance, and the latent tendency of conceit troubles, the latent tendency of
mnd7:9.11: greed and defilements, the latent tendency of ignorance defilements, and the
mnd7:9.12: pollution that coexists with them are far away from the outside and everything.
mnd7:10.1: What is keeping away (in adherence)? Relying on the known as the pollution and
mnd7:10.2: various aggregates and various works; relying on distance is called non-living,
mnd7:10.3: Nibbāna, that is the cessation of all actions, the cessation of all dependence,
mnd7:10.4: the extinction of craving, greed, extinguishment, and Nibbāna, this is to stay
mnd7:10.5: away. Being far away in body belongs to being away from desires; being far away
mnd7:10.6: in mind (heart) belongs to the pure, reaching the highest purity; being far away
mnd7:10.7: in adherence belongs to the unattached person, who comes to leave the world. "We
mnd7:10.8: will learn from far away": The one who is here is already a learner. In
mnd7:10.9: addition, this is said by the hearers of the teaching of the Dhamma.
mnd7:14.1: "Metteyya": The Blessed One calls the person who has taken the seat by his
mnd7:14.2: surname. "Blessed One" is synonymous with respect. In addition, "destroyed
mnd7:14.3: greed" is the Blessed One; "destroyed wicked" is the Blessed One; "destroyed
mnd7:14.4: ignorance" is the Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed the conceit" is the
mnd7:14.5: Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed the sight" is the Blessed One; "the one
mnd7:14.6: who has destroyed the thorns" is the Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed the
mnd7:14.7: pollutants" is the Blessed One; "the one who is ended" is the Blessed One; "the
mnd7:14.8: one who has practiced the body, the precepts, the mind, and the wisdom" is the
mnd7:14.9: Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is close to the woods, wild forests, and border
mnd7:14.10: dwellings (sitting places): low sound, quiet, away from the human atmosphere,
mnd7:14.11: who lives alone, and is suitable for sitting alone" is the Blessed One; or the
mnd7:14.12: Blessed One is the one who divides clothes, food, shelter, the needs of the
mnd7:14.13: sick, and medical necessities; or "the Blessed One is the one who has the taste
mnd7:14.14: of righteousness, the taste of Dhamma, the taste of liberation, the precepts,
mnd7:14.15: the mind, and the wisdom" is the World Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is the
mnd7:14.16: one with four types of jhāna, four immeasurables, four formlessness, etc.; or
mnd7:14.17: "the Blessed One is the Participant of the Eight Liberations, the Eight Victory
mnd7:14.18: Places, and the Ninth Dwelling Places, etc.;" the one who is purely divided is
mnd7:14.19: the Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is the one who divides the four
mnd7:14.20: mindfulness, the four righteousness, the four bases, the five roots, the five
mnd7:14.21: powers, the seven enlightenment factors, and the eight branches of the holy
mnd7:14.22: path." The Blessed One is the one who has ten Tathāgata strength, four
mnd7:14.23: fearlessness, four unobstructed solutions, six magical powers, and six
mnd7:14.24: enlightenment methods." The Blessed One is the Blessed One. "The Blessed One,"
mnd7:14.25: this name is not given (made) by the mother; not given by the father; not given
mnd7:14.26: by brothers; not by sisters; not by friends; not by relatives; not by Samaṇas or
mnd7:14.27: Brāhmaṇas; not by heaven. This is ultimate liberation; to Buddha, the World
mnd7:14.28: Honored person, and under the Bodhi tree together with all the knowledge and
mnd7:14.29: wisdom gained and testimony, that is, the Blessed One.
mnd7:15.1: "To even forget the precepts": Forget the precepts in two ways: forget the
mnd7:15.2: precepts of the teachings, and the precepts of the Path. What is the learned
mnd7:15.3: commandment? For him, those who have learned Suttas, Geyya, Veyyākaraṇa, Gātha,
mnd7:15.4: Udāna, Itivuttaka, Jātaka, Abbhuta Dhamma, Vedalla, this is learned teaching
mnd7:15.5: commandment. He forgets, completely forgets, forcefully forgets, completely
mnd7:15.6: forcefully forgets, and becomes an outsider.
mnd7:16.1: What are the Path precepts? The correct path, the following path, the uninverted
mnd7:16.2: path, the meaning of the path, the path where one follows the Dhamma, the
mnd7:16.3: completeness of the precepts, the guardian of the roots, the right amount of
mnd7:16.4: food, the sober practice, mindfulness and right knowledge, four mindfulness,
mnd7:16.5: four righteousness, four spiritual bases (iddhipāda), five senses, five powers,
mnd7:16.6: seven enlightenment factors, eight branches of the holy Path, this is the Path
mnd7:16.7: precept. He forgets, completely forgets, strongly forgets, and completely
mnd7:17.1: "Acting wrongly": Killing, taking without giving, invading people's homes,
mnd7:17.2: taking predations (looting), blocking roads, robbing, abducting wives, saying
mnd7:18.1: "For him this is unholy": For that person this is unsacred, foolish, ignorant,
mnd7:18.2: deceit dhamma, that is: the evil path.
mnd7:19.3: He is like a stray cart in the world;
mnd7:19.4: They say he is a bad, ordinary man.
mnd7:19.7: He is like a stray cart in the world;
mnd7:19.8: They say he is a bad, ordinary man.

mnd7:19.15: He is like a stray cart in the world;
mnd7:19.16: They say he is a bad, ordinary man.
mnd7:20.1: "After previously walking alone": After previously walking alone in two ways: as
mnd7:20.2: a bhikkhu or abandonment of the masses. How does one alone as a bhikkhu? After
mnd7:20.3: cutting off all obstacles at home, cutting off the obstacles of children and
mnd7:20.4: wives, cutting off the obstacles of relatives, cutting off the obstacles of
mnd7:20.5: friends, cutting off the obstacles of storage, after cutting off the hair and
mnd7:20.6: beards, putting on the robes, going from home to a non-domestic (monastic) life,
mnd7:20.7: one should walk alone, live, act, go on, guard, and survive, after starting to
mnd7:20.8: become in a state of nothing. In this way, one should go alone becoming a
mnd7:21.1: How to walk alone by abandoning the masses? When he became a bhikkhu in this
mnd7:21.2: way, he was alone in the woods, wild forests, ...; he walked alone, stood
mnd7:21.3: alone...; this is abandoning the masses to walk alone.
mnd7:22.1: "Anyone who engages in lust": Anyone who is not in the right way...
mnd7:22.2: (omitted)..., for that reason is called the dhamma of lust. "Anyone who engages
mnd7:22.3: in lust": Anyone who abandons the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, learns and then
mnd7:22.4: returns to secular life, engages in, turns to engage in, fully engages, and
mnd7:23.1: "He is like a stray cart ride in the world": "Cart ride," stray, unmanned,
mnd7:23.2: unmade, untrained elephant cart ride, horse cart ride, ox cart ride, goat
mnd7:23.3: carriage ride, ram cart ride, camel cart ride, donkey carriage ride; it takes a
mnd7:23.4: side road, climbs up uneven stubbles and rocks, destroys the boarded carts and
mnd7:23.5: rides, and falls into the cliff. Like the stray, uncontrollable, unmanned, and
mnd7:23.6: untrained cart ride takes the side way. Similarly, the vulgar person, like the
mnd7:23.7: stray cart ride, he takes the side way (evil way) and takes the evil view...
mnd7:23.8: (omitted) to take the evil mind. The stray, untuned, unmanned, untrained rides
mnd7:23.9: climbed on the uneven stubbles and rocks. Similarly, the vulgar person boarded
mnd7:23.10: the uneven body kamma, ascend to the improper language kamma, ascend the
mnd7:23.11: improper mental kamma, ascend the improper killing, ascend the imperfectly to
mnd7:23.12: take without giving, ascend the improper licentiousness, descend as the improper
mnd7:23.13: fraud, descend on the irregularities, on the rough and bad language of the
mnd7:23.14: irregularities, on the offensive language on the irregularities, on the greed of
mnd7:23.15: the irregularities, on the malice of the irregularities, on the evil views of
mnd7:23.16: the irregularities, on the various things of the irregularities, going, climb up
mnd7:23.17: the five desires of unevenness, and climb the covers of unevenness. As the
mnd7:23.18: stray, unmanned, unmade, untrained ride destroys the boarded ride, the same, the
mnd7:23.19: person who returned to the secular world was like a stray cart. He destroyed
mnd7:23.20: himself in hell, in the animal world, in the hungry ghost world, in the human
mnd7:23.21: world, and in the heavenly world. Like the stray, untuned, unmade, untrained car
mnd7:23.22: ride falling off the cliff, the same, the vulgar person falls into the cliff of
mnd7:23.23: life, the cliff of age, the cliff of disease, into the cliff of death, the cliff
mnd7:23.24: of sorrow and despair. "In the world," in the world of suffering, in the world
mnd7:24.1: "They say: the inferior ordinary man": "Ordinary man," what is the meaning of
mnd7:24.2: ordinary man? "They cause a lot of pollution to arise" are ordinary people;
mnd7:24.3: "Many people who have not removed" are ordinary people; "Those who see the faces
mnd7:24.4: of many masters" are ordinary people; "Those who have not come out of many
mnd7:24.5: things of interest" are ordinary people; "They made many types of things." For
mnd7:24.6: ordinary people; "They were swept away by many types of violent currents." For
mnd7:24.7: ordinary people; "They were annoyed by many types of torments." For ordinary
mnd7:24.8: people; "They were burned out by many types of heat. "For ordinary people; "the
mnd7:24.9: one who is greedy, craving, bound, obsessed, tainted, attached, fixed, and
mnd7:24.10: obstructed by the five desires" is ordinary; "covered and enclosed by the five
mnd7:24.11: types of desires, obstructed, closed, covered." "They say: inferior ordinary
mnd7:24.12: people": They say so, speak so, talk so, explain, say: inferior, despicable,
mnd7:25.4: He should learn and give up his lust.
mnd7:25.8: He should learn and give up his lust.
mnd7:25.12: He should learn and give up his lust.
mnd7:25.16: He should learn and give up his lust.
mnd7:26.1: "Any previous glory and praise, his may even be abandoned": What is glory? Here,
mnd7:26.2: a certain type of people (in their previous state as a Samaṇa) are honored,
mnd7:26.3: respected, revered, (with) clothes, food, shelter, the patient's needs and the
mnd7:26.4: medical necessities, this is glory. What is praise? Here, a certain type of
mnd7:26.5: people came to praise when they were in the previous Samaṇa state. They are the
mnd7:26.6: wise, the learned, the hearer, and the eloquent, those who are good at defending
mnd7:26.7: arguments, and skillful: "the chanter (the teacher)," or the "lawyer," or the
mnd7:26.8: "speaker," or the "lives in the forest," or the "beggar," or "wears dung
mnd7:26.9: sweeper," or "three-clothed person," or "second beggar," or "not eaten after
mnd7:26.10: eating," or "usually sitting (not lying)," or "living anywhere," or "the gainer
mnd7:26.11: of the first jhāna," or "the gainer of the second jhāna," or "the gainer of the
mnd7:26.12: third jhāna," or the "the gainer of the fourth jhāna," or "the gainer of the
mnd7:26.13: boundless void," or "the gainer of boundless consciousness," or "the gainer of
mnd7:26.14: nothingness," or the "the gainer who does not dwell in nothingness
mnd7:27.1: "His may even be abandoned." After a while, when he gave up the Buddha, Dhamma,
mnd7:27.2: Saṅgha, learned and then returned to vulgarity, that glory and that reputation
mnd7:27.3: declined, declined, (was) lost, disappeared, and shattered.
mnd7:28.1: "After seeing this, he should learn, he should give up his lust": "This," the
mnd7:28.2: glory and praise in the previous state as a Samaṇa; later, when he gave up the
mnd7:28.3: Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, learned and returned to the vulgar, there is no glory
mnd7:28.4: and no reputation, this is to achieve failure. "After seeing," ...."He should
mnd7:28.5: learn." There are three learnings: increase precept learning, increase mind
mnd7:29.1: What is to increase precepts? Here, the bhikkhu is a preceptor who lives and is
mnd7:29.2: protected by the self-control of the Pātimokkha. He has sufficient righteousness
mnd7:29.3: and state of affairs. He sees the horror in minor sins and learns after
mnd7:29.4: accepting from a teacher. Small precepts aggregate and large precept aggregates
mnd7:29.5: are the foundation of abstinence, the (self) inhibition of behavior, the
mnd7:29.6: entrance of self-control, the uppermost of good dhamma, etc., this is to
mnd7:30.1: What is to increase mind? Here, the bhikkhu lives in the first jhāna of
mnd7:30.2: reasoning and thinking after he is absent from desires and unwholesome Dhamma,
mnd7:30.3: and after detachment produces joy and happiness; he calms down reasoning and
mnd7:30.4: thinking, with confidence, and one mind, and after entering, he lives in no
mnd7:30.5: reasoning, the second jhāna of joy and happiness is born without waiting;
mnd7:30.6: concentration, which fades with joy and dwells in peace, has mindfulness and
mnd7:30.7: right knowledge, and feels happiness in the body, after entering, dwelling in,
mnd7:30.8: this holy disciple proclaims: "He is calm and possessed" in the third jhāna of
mnd7:30.9: "mindfulness and abiding in the bliss;" with the renunciation of pleasure and
mnd7:30.10: the renunciation of suffering, and the extinction of joy and sorrow in the past,
mnd7:30.11: after entering, dwells in where there is no suffering or unhappiness in the
mnd7:30.12: fourth jhāna, this is to increase the mind.
mnd7:31.1: What is to increase wisdom? Here, the bhikkhu is a wise person, possessing the
mnd7:31.2: wisdom that leads to the arising and passing away; the holy, insight, and the
mnd7:31.3: complete extinction of suffering is (the wisdom), he truthfully knows "This is
mnd7:31.4: suffering." I know "This is the collection of suffering." I know "This is
mnd7:31.5: suffering." I know "This is the path to suffering." To know the truth: "These
mnd7:31.6: are troubles." To know the truth: "This is a collection of troubles." To know
mnd7:31.7: the truth: "This is the elimination of suffering." To know the truth: "This is
mnd7:31.8: the path leading to suffering." This is to increase wisdom. Anyone who is acting
mnd7:31.9: not in the Dhamma... (omitted) is called the dhamma of lust..., for that reason
mnd7:31.10: it is called the dhamma of lust.
mnd7:32.1: "After seeing this, he should learn, he should abandon lust." For the
mnd7:32.2: abandonment, calming, stopping, and cessation of lust, he should learn to
mnd7:32.3: increase precepts, he should also learn to increase mind, and he should also
mnd7:32.4: learn to increase wisdom. These three studies should be learned when heading
mnd7:32.5: towards (noting); learning when knowing; learning when seeing; learning when
mnd7:32.6: introspecting; learning when establishing (decision) when the heart is
mnd7:32.7: established; learning when solving with faith; you should learn when you are
mnd7:32.8: vigorous; you should learn when mindfulness arises; you should learn when mind
mnd7:32.9: concentration arises; you should learn when you know with wisdom; you should
mnd7:32.10: learn when you know what should be known; you should learn when you should be
mnd7:32.11: renounced; you should learn when practicing should be practiced; you should
mnd7:32.12: learn when testifying what should be testified [Ps.1,41], you should practice,
mnd7:32.13: you should practiced well, and you should go on after accepting.

mnd7:34.1: "He was defeated by his intention, and he thought like a miserable person": The
mnd7:34.2: intention to to desire, malicious intention, the intention to harm, the
mnd7:34.3: intention to see, touched, tortured, combined, possessed, covered; he thought,
mnd7:34.4: thought strongly, thought with all types of thoughts, after leaving there,
mnd7:34.5: thinking like a miserable person, like a dull person, like an extremely foolish
mnd7:34.6: person. Like an owl looking for a mouse on a branch and thinking hard, thinking
mnd7:34.7: with all types of thinking, thinking after leaving there; like a jackal looking
mnd7:34.8: for a fish on a river bank, ...; like a cat looking for mice in gaps, sewers,
mnd7:34.9: garbage dumps, ...; like a donkey that has been unburdened, in the alley, in the
mnd7:34.10: sewer, in the garbage dump, ... [MN.50]; in the same way, the intention of the
mnd7:34.11: person who returned to the secular (life) was to desire, malicious intention,
mnd7:34.12: intention to harm, the intention to see touches, tortures, combines, possesses,
mnd7:34.13: and covers. He thinks, thinks strongly, uses all types of thoughts, and after
mnd7:34.14: leaving there, he thinks like a miserable person, like a dull person, like an
mnd7:35.1: "After hearing this blame from others, people like that type become ashamed":
mnd7:35.2: "Others," a parent teacher, or teacher, or equivalent to a teacher, or a friend,
mnd7:35.3: or acquaintance, or close person, or peer supervision: "Mendicants! After you
mnd7:35.4: get a great master like this, become a bhikkhu in such a well-spoken Dhamma, and
mnd7:35.5: get a holy group like this, after giving up the bad lust dhamma, the Buddha,
mnd7:35.6: Dhamma, Saṅgha, and after learning, returning to the vulgar (secular life), it
mnd7:35.7: is not your gain for that; for that it is your evil gain. There is indeed no
mnd7:35.8: faith in you in the good Dhamma, there is no shame in the good Dhamma, there is
mnd7:35.9: indeed no (none of your) vitality in good Dhamma, indeed there is no thought of
mnd7:35.10: you in good Dhamma, and indeed there is no wisdom of you in good Dhamma."
mnd7:35.11: [AN.5.5] He will hear, grasp, understand, distinguish their words, ways of
mnd7:35.12: speaking, teaching, and admonitions teachings and become ashamed, oppressed,
mnd7:35.13: struck, and distressed, and become in a state of worry. "Like that type of
mnd7:35.14: person": Like that type, like that kind, belonging to that type of residence,
mnd7:35.15: that type of thing like that, he that has returned to vulgarity.

mnd7:36.15: This is indeed a big cave,
mnd7:37.1: "He makes swords again, when he is urged by the words of others": "Again," the
mnd7:37.2: sentence continuation; .... "Swords (knives)," there are three types of knives:
mnd7:37.3: body knives, speech knives, and intention knives; three knives of bodily deeds,
mnd7:37.4: four knives of speech deeds, and three knives of intention deeds. "When urged by
mnd7:37.5: others," when urged by a parent teacher, or teacher, ..., he deliberately said
mnd7:37.6: vainly. He said, "Great Virtue! I am a joyful bhikkhu, (but) for me, I should
mnd7:37.7: support my mother, so I returned to the secular life." He said: "For me, I
mnd7:37.8: should support my father...." He said, "...I should raise my brother, ...I
mnd7:37.9: should raise sisters..., I should raise my son..., ...my daughter..., ...should
mnd7:37.11: so I returned to vulgarity." It is a speech knife; he makes it happen, makes it
mnd7:38.1: "This will indeed be a big cave": This is his big cave, big forest, big dense
mnd7:38.2: forest, big dangerous road, big danger, big bend, big mud mud, big obstacle, big
mnd7:39.1: "He jumped into false speech": false speech is called falsehoods. Here, a
mnd7:39.2: certain type of person comes to the temple, or to the assembly, or to the
mnd7:39.3: relatives, or to the group, or to the palace, and is brought as a witness for
mnd7:39.4: questioning: "Come, man! Please tell me what you know of the way." He says
mnd7:39.5: without knowing: "I know." Or, if he knows it, he says: "I don't know." He
mnd7:39.6: doesn't see it and says, "I see." Or, when he sees it, he says, "I didn't see
mnd7:39.7: it." Like this, he deliberately speaks vainly based on his own cause, or the
mnd7:39.8: cause of others, or because of a little temptation.
mnd7:40.1: Or, taking three behaviors as "lies": just before (saying) (thinking): "I will
mnd7:40.2: say lies." When said, (thinking): "I'm speaking lies." When I have said it,
mnd7:40.3: (thinking): "I have said the lies." Or, taking four behaviors: just before
mnd7:40.4: (saying), (thinking): "I will say a lie." When said, (thinking): "I'm speaking
mnd7:40.5: lies." When it has been said (thinking): "I have said the lies." There are
mnd7:40.6: opinions of different attachments (errors), and these four behaviors are
mnd7:40.7: regarded as lie. Or, take five forms..., six forms..., seven forms..., eight
mnd7:40.8: forms as lies: Before saying.... There are (wrong) opinions of different
mnd7:40.9: attachments, the likes of different attachments, the inclinations of different
mnd7:40.10: attachments, the desires of different attachments, and the nature of different
mnd7:40.11: attachments. These eight behaviors are regarded as lies and false words. "He
mnd7:40.12: jumped into false speech": He jumped in, dove into, entered false speech.
mnd7:41.1: <em>55 : (He was known as) a famous wise man
mnd7:41.4: He is dragged around like a dull person.
mnd7:41.5: <em>55 : (He was known as) a famous wise man
mnd7:41.8: He is dragged around like a dull person.

mnd7:41.12: He is dragged around like a dull person.
mnd7:41.13: <em>55 : (He was known as) a famous wise man
mnd7:41.16: He is dragged around like a dull person.
mnd7:42.1: "Famous wise man": Here, a certain type of person came to glory and praise when
mnd7:42.2: he was in the previous state as a Samaṇa: .... In this way, he is known and
mnd7:43.1: "Solo traveler": There are two ways to travel alone: ....
mnd7:44.1: "But when he is united with lust": Whoever is not doing justice.... "But when he
mnd7:44.2: is united in lust": After a while, he abandons the Buddha, Dhamma, the Saṅgha,
mnd7:44.3: learns and then returns to the secular world, is bound in the lust....
mnd7:45.1: "Like a dull person being pulled around": The miserable person is like a dull
mnd7:45.2: person, like a very foolish person being dragged, pulled around, getting into
mnd7:45.3: trouble: killing, taking without giving, ..., saying falsehoods, so that he was
mnd7:45.4: dragged, dragged around, and got into trouble. After the king caught him, he was
mnd7:45.5: punished with various punishments: whipping, beating with a stick, beating with
mnd7:45.6: a cane, cutting off his hands, feet, hands and feet, ears, nose, ears and nose,
mnd7:45.7: tortured by sour porridge pot penalties, shell-bald penalties, Rāhu's's mouth
mnd7:45.8: penalties, fire torture penalties, candle hand penalties, exorcism penalties,
mnd7:45.9: bark coat penalties, antelope penalties, hook flesh penalties, money penalties,
mnd7:45.10: alkali bathing, twisting the door latch, stepping on the straw, drenching hot
mnd7:45.11: oil, causing a dog to bite, piercing while alive, beheading with a sword, so
mnd7:45.12: that he is dragged, dragged around, and gets into trouble.
mnd7:46.1: Or, conquered with desire and thirst, the heart is occupied, as when the ship
mnd7:46.2: leaped into the sea, tormented by the cold and heat, by the contact of fly
mnd7:46.3: mosquitoes, wind, sun, and snake, to die of hunger and thirst; and go to
mnd7:46.4: (omitted: various locations are listed here, including Taxila, Java, Tambapanṇị̄,
mnd7:46.5: and many unknown places — B. Bodhi also omits this list from the commentary); go
mnd7:46.6: to the dangerous road in the desert; go on the knees to the road that can be
mnd7:46.7: passed; the road where goats go; the road that can only be passed when supported
mnd7:46.8: by pillars; the road that can only be passed by holding a parachute; the road
mnd7:46.9: that can only be passed when the bamboo bush is cut; To the bird road; to the
mnd7:46.10: mouse road; to the cracked road; walked to the vine-walking road, so that he was
mnd7:46.11: dragged, pulled around, and got into trouble.
mnd7:47.1: When he was seeking, he did not find it, and felt distressed because of not
mnd7:47.2: getting it, so he was dragged, pulled around, and got into trouble.
mnd7:48.1: When he sought, he found it, and felt distressed because of the protection he
mnd7:48.2: got: "Whether my belongings will be taken away by the king, the thieves will not
mnd7:48.3: take it away, the fire will not burn, and the water will not flow away, the
mnd7:48.4: unloved heirs will not take it away." When he guards and protects in this way,
mnd7:48.5: his property is destroyed, he is rooted in separation and feels distress, so he
mnd7:48.6: is dragged, pulled around, and got into trouble.
mnd7:49.1: <em>56 : Muni, here, after knowing this affliction
mnd7:49.3: He will be firm on his own
mnd7:49.4: And will not engage in lust.

mnd7:50.1: "Muni, here, before and after, after knowing this affliction": "This," there was
mnd7:50.2: glory and praise when he was in the state as a Samaṇa before, and there was no
mnd7:50.3: glory and praise when he gave up the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, learned and
mnd7:50.4: returned to the secular life afterwards. This attainment and loss. "After
mnd7:51.1: "Muni," Muni is called wisdom, that is wisdom, understanding... (omitted), no
mnd7:51.2: delusion, Dhamma, right view, possessing Muni wisdom, Muni. There are three
mnd7:51.3: types of Muni (perfect virtues): body Muni, language Muni, and intention Muni.
mnd7:52.1: What is the body of Muni? The three types of body and evil deeds are cut off as
mnd7:52.2: the Muni position; the three types of good behaviors are the Muni position; the
mnd7:52.3: wisdom in the body is the Muni position; the knowledge of the body is the Muni
mnd7:52.4: position; walking the Path with (higher) knowledge is the body of Muni; the
mnd7:52.5: abandonment of desire and greed, cut off, as the Muni; the fourth jhāna
mnd7:52.6: extinction of the body is the position of Muni.
mnd7:53.1: What is the language of Muni? The abandonment of the four types of evil deeds of
mnd7:53.2: language is the position of Muni; the four types of good acts of language are
mnd7:53.3: the position of Muni; the wisdom of linguistic objects is the position of Muni;
mnd7:53.4: the knowledge of language is the position of Muni; and knowing the path of all
mnd7:53.5: acts is the position of Muni; the abandonment of desire and greed of language is
mnd7:53.6: the position of Muni; the second jhāna cessation of language is the position of
mnd7:54.1: What is intention Muni? The three types of deeds of intention and evil deeds are
mnd7:54.2: the Muni position; the three types of good deeds are the Muni position; the
mnd7:54.3: wisdom in the mind-object is the Muni position; the knowledge of the heart is
mnd7:54.4: the Muni position; the one that walks the Path with knowledge is the position of
mnd7:54.5: Muni; the desire and greed of the heart being judged is the position of Muni;
mnd7:54.6: the desire to perish the mind is the position of Muni.
mnd7:55.1: "Body Muni, Language Muni, and Intention Muni are no troubles,
mnd7:55.2: Muni has the status of Muni, and they say he is the one who cuts everything.
mnd7:55.3: Body Muni, Language Muni, and Intention Muni are no troubles,
mnd7:55.4: Muni has the status of Muni, and they say that they are those who have been cleansed of evil."
mnd7:56.1: The six types of Muni have these three modes of Muni: Muni at home, Muni without
mnd7:56.2: a home, Muni with learning, Muni without learning, Bhikkhu Muni, Muni (of the)
mnd7:56.3: Muni. Which is at home? Those laymen who have seen the footsteps and have
mnd7:56.4: learned the precepts, these are at home. Which are homeless Muni? Those bhikkhus
mnd7:56.5: who have seen the footsteps and who have learned the precepts are homeless Muni.
mnd7:56.6: There are seven types of learning for learning Muni, Arahant for non-learning
mnd7:56.7: Muni, and Bhikkhu Buddha as Bhikkhu Muni. Muni (of) Muni is called Tathāgata,
mnd7:57.1: "Non-wise is Muni, a foolish and ignorant man,
mnd7:57.2: After raising the scale, take the top one and become a wise man.
mnd7:57.3: Avoid all evils, that Muni became Muni because of that,
mnd7:57.4: Everyone who understands the (inner and outer sum) in the world,
mnd7:57.5: Because that is said to be Muni.
mnd7:57.6: Who knows all the inside and outside of the world,
mnd7:57.7: The unwholesome and the good behind the Dhamma,
mnd7:57.8: Everyone who is supported (respected) by heaven and man,
mnd7:57.9: Beyond staining and the net, he is Muni."
mnd7:58.1: "Here," belongs to this view, belongs to this love, belongs to this inclination,
mnd7:58.2: in this attachment, in this dhamma, in this teaching language, in these
mnd7:58.3: scriptures, in the teachings of this master, in this individual, in this human
mnd7:59.1: "He will be firm on his own": In two ways he will firmly be alone: in the name
mnd7:59.2: of a bhikkhu or in the renunciation of the masses. How can he do so firmly in
mnd7:59.3: the as a bhikkhu? After cutting off all the obstacles at home, ..., and survive,
mnd7:59.4: so that he will firmly walk alone as a bhikkhu.
mnd7:60.1: How can he do his own way firmly with the rejection of the masses? When he is a
mnd7:60.2: bhikkhu like this, he will be alone in the woods, ..., and survive, so that he
mnd7:60.3: will be firmly committed to acting alone by giving up the masses. He will be
mnd7:60.4: firm and alone, he will be a firm holder of good Dhamma; he will be a holder of
mnd7:61.1: "Will not engage in lust": Whoever is not doing justice.... He will not get
mnd7:61.2: close to or engage in the dhamma of lust, will not participate, will not be
mnd7:61.3: used, will not practice, will not practice fully, will not be held after going
mnd7:62.1: <em>57 : He should learn to stay away,
mnd7:62.2: This is the supreme of all holy ones,
mnd7:62.3: (But) he should not think that he is the most victorious because of that,
mnd7:62.4: In front of the one which is indeed Nibbāna.
mnd7:62.5: <em>57 : He should learn to stay away,
mnd7:62.6: This is the supreme of all holy ones,
mnd7:62.7: (But) he should not think that he is the most victorious because of that,
mnd7:62.8: In front of the one which is indeed Nibbāna.
mnd7:62.9: <em>57 : He should learn to stay away,
mnd7:62.10: This is the supreme of all holy ones,
mnd7:62.11: (But) he should not think that he is the most victorious because of that,
mnd7:62.12: In front of the one which is indeed Nibbāna.
mnd7:62.13: <em>57 : He should learn to stay away,
mnd7:62.14: This is the supreme of all holy ones,
mnd7:62.15: (But) he should not think that he is the most victorious because of that,
mnd7:62.16: In front of the one which is indeed Nibbāna.
mnd7:63.1: "He should learn to stay away": "To stay away," there are three types of staying
mnd7:63.2: away: .... "He should learn." There are three types of learning: .... "He should
mnd7:63.3: learn to stay away": He should learn, practice, practice well, and go away after
mnd7:64.1: "This is the supreme of all the holy ones": All the saints are called the
mnd7:64.2: Buddhas and the disciples of the Buddhas and the Bhikkhus. This is the first,
mnd7:64.3: the most victorious, the supreme, the top, and the highest among the saints,
mnd7:64.4: that is: staying away from the deeds.
mnd7:65.1: "(But) he should not think that he is the most victorious because of that":
mnd7:65.2: Should not, because of being far away, accept tribute, be lofty, arrogant, have
mnd7:65.3: fortitude, be stubborn, and be arrogant, these should not be made because of
mnd7:65.4: that. He shouldn't be a rigid, very stiff, head-raising person because of that.
mnd7:66.1: "In front of the one which is truly Nibbāna": In front of, near, close to, not
mnd7:66.2: far away, near the one which is Nibbāna.
mnd7:67.2: Who has no expectation in desire,
mnd7:67.3: Those who are bound in their desire
mnd7:67.4: Envy those who have survived the torrent.
mnd7:67.6: Who has no expectation in desire,
mnd7:67.7: Those who are bound in their desire
mnd7:67.8: Envy those who have survived the torrent.
mnd7:67.10: Who has no expectation in desire,
mnd7:67.11: Those who are bound in their desire
mnd7:67.12: Envy those who have survived the torrent.
mnd7:67.14: Who has no expectation in desire,
mnd7:67.15: Those who are bound in their desire
mnd7:67.16: Envy those who have survived the torrent.
mnd7:68.1: "Muni, who is empty (void)": Empty, far away, separated, void of evil doings,
mnd7:68.2: far away, separated with the body; evil deeds with the words... ; ...with
mnd7:68.3: intention...; with greed, hatred, delusion, anger, resentment, hiding evil,
mnd7:68.4: domineering, jealousy, stinginess, hypocrisy, cunning, stubbornness, passion,
mnd7:68.5: conceit, arrogance, ease (lack of effort), all pollution, all evil, all
mnd7:68.6: troubles, all scorching, all heat (torment); ...with all unwholesomeness, made
mnd7:68.7: empty, far away, and separated. "Muni," .... "When walking" means walking,
mnd7:68.8: staying, acting, going on, guarding, and surviving.
mnd7:69.1: "Those who have no expectation in desire": "Desire," there are two types of
mnd7:69.2: desires: the desire of things and the desire of pollution .... After the desires
mnd7:69.3: of things are known, after giving up, after abandoning, after being driven away,
mnd7:69.4: after the end, after making it non-existent, when the desire for things is not
mnd7:69.5: expected, he becomes the one who has given up his desires, those who have
mnd7:69.6: eliminated their desires, those who have released their desires, those who have
mnd7:69.7: abandoned their desires, those who have ceased their desires, those who have
mnd7:69.8: renounced greed, those who have left greed, those who have forgone greed, those
mnd7:69.9: who have ceased to be greedy, those who are not hungry and thirsty, those who
mnd7:69.10: have cooled down, those who have become cool, those who feel happy, and those
mnd7:69.11: who live by themselves as Brāhmaṇa.
mnd7:70.1: "People who are tied up in desire are envious of those who have survived the
mnd7:70.2: torrent": "People" are synonymous with all beings. People are greedy, covetous,
mnd7:70.3: bound, infatuated, tainted, attached to their desires, fixed, obstructed, they
mnd7:70.4: want, accept, hope, aspire, and pray for those who have passed the torrent of
mnd7:70.5: desire; ...have passed the torrent of sight...; ...have passed the torrent of
mnd7:70.6: ignorance..; those who have passed, have come out, have crossed, have
mnd7:70.7: transcended, have overcome; have reached the ultimate, have reached the end;
mnd7:70.8: those who have reached the end, have reached the boundary (ultimate); those who
mnd7:70.9: have reached the boundary, have reached the end; those who have reached the end,
mnd7:70.10: have arrived at the shelter; those who have reached the shelter, have reached
mnd7:70.11: the refuge; those who have reached the refuge, have reached safety; those who
mnd7:70.12: have reached safety, have reached no terror; those who have reached no terror,
mnd7:70.13: have reached no death; those who have reached no death, have reached the
mnd7:70.14: undeath; those who have reached the undeath, have reached extinction; those who
mnd7:70.15: have reached extinction, have reached the Nibbāna.
mnd7:71.1: Such as the debtor desires and envies being debt-free; such as the sick who
mnd7:71.2: desires and envy being free from disease; such as those bound by fetters who
mnd7:71.3: desire and envy to be free from the fetters; as the slave desires and envies of
mnd7:71.4: being free from being the slave; such as those who jump into the difficult road
mnd7:71.5: hope and envy stability as the ultimate place. Similarly, people are greedy,
mnd7:71.6: craving, bound, obsessed, tainted, attached, fixed, and obstructed in their
mnd7:71.7: desires. They want, accept, hope, aspire, and pray for those who have passed the
mnd7:71.8: torrent of desire; ...; those who have reached Nibbāna.
